data.Author: Abdullah
data.Title: Effects of deep breath on blood pressure in normo-prehypertension subjects
data.Journal: European Journal of Molecular & Clinical Medicine
data.Overall effect: Deep Breathing descreased SBP and DBP significantly,especially in the first minute followed with third and fifth minutes.

data.Author: Ahmed
data.Title: Effect of Box Breathing Technique on Lung Function Test
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Lung functions (FVC, FEV1, FEV1/FVC, FEF 25-75, PEFR, FIVC)
data.Overall effect: There was a significant increase among the participants FVC (Forced Vital Capacity), FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume), FIVC (Forced Inspiratory Vital Capacity) parameters after 2 sessions on each day of box breathing technique for a period of 30 days.

data.Author: Aktaş
data.Title: The Effect of Deep Breathing Exercise and 4-7-8 Breathing Techniques Applied to Patients After Bariatric Surgery on Anxiety and Quality of Life
data.Population: Individuals who had undergone bariatric surgery
data.Population category (students, general,: Bariatric surgery patients at Ankara Lokman Hekim Akay Hospital, Endocrinology and Metabolism Diseases Clinic
data.Overall effect: The diference between that the StateTrait Anxiety Inventory and OSQLS mean scores was similar and was not statistically signifcant in the pre-test in each of the three groups, the state anxiety level decreased in the post-test compared to the pre-test in the intra-group comparison of the 4–7-8 breathing technique group, the anxiety level of the 4–7-8 breathing technique group was lower and statistically signifcant compared to both groups, and the quality of life score increased in the post-test compared to the pre-test in the intra-group comparison of the deep breathing group

data.Author: Anasuya
data.Title: Effect of slow breathing on autonomic tone & baroreflex sensitivity in yoga practitioners
data.Age: Mean age (yoga group): 29.93 yrs, mean age (control): 31.08 yrs
data.Overall effect: Study indicated higher parasympathetic activity and BRS with lower SBP variability at rest and during slow breathing in yoga practitioners compared to naive group. Findings indicate that the short-term practice of slow breathing complements the augmented parasympathetic activity and BRS in the yoga group.

data.Author: Anika
data.Title: A Study to Assess the Effectiveness of Deep Breathing Exercise on Blood Pressure and Heart Rate Among Hypertensive Patients in Selected Area of Kheda District
data.Journal: Indian Journal of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing led to a reduction in blood pressure and heart rate in hypertensive patients

data.Author: Ankad Roopa
data.Title: Effect of short term pranayama and meditation on respiratory parameters in healthy individuals
data.Journal: International Journal of Collaborative Research on Internal Medicine & Public Health
data.Type of breathing practice: Vibhagiya Pranayama, Nadishuddi Pranayama, Kapalabathi Kriya, Bahya Pranayama, Cooling Pranayama
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Respiratory function (chest expansion, breath holding time, peak expiratory flow rate)
data.Overall effect: Study showed beneficial effects of short term (15 days) regular pranayama and meditation practice on respiratory functions

data.Author: Ariga
data.Title: Decrease Anxiety among Students Who Will Do the Objective Structured Clinical Examination with Deep Breathing Relaxation Technique
data.Journal: Open Access Macedonian Journal of Medical Sciences
data.Overall effect: There was a decrease in student anxiety with deep breath relaxation

data.Author: Arsenault
data.Title: Pain modulation induced by respiration: phase and frequency effects
data.Study design: Repeated measures (can we call this pre post)
data.Type of breathing practice: Slow breathing (0.1 Hz w/varied inhalation/exhalation times and 0.2 Hz)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Pain perception, electrophysiological measures of spinal and cerebral activity
data.Overall effect: Manipulation of respiration parameters produced a very small effect on pain and the associated brain activity. However, significant changes were limited to the respiration phase while the respiration frequency did not affect pain or brain activity

data.Author: Awan
data.Title: Effect of deep breathing exercises in healthy smokers: A pilot study
data.Population category (students, general,: Smokers with minimum smoking history of 5 years
data.Type of breathing practice: Pursed lip breathing, diaphragmatic breathing, powered breathing
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Lung functions (vital capacity, inspiratory capacity, tidal volume, etc.)
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing exercise techniques were found to be useful in healthy smokers for improving lung functions and delaying the development of chronic obstructive lung complications

data.Author: Babamohamadi
data.Title: The Effect of Rhythmic Breathing on the Severity of Sternotomy Pain after Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial
data.Overall effect: The effect of RB on post-CABG sternotomy pain control confirmed that RB was effective in reducing the severity of sternotomy pain after surgery in the intervention group

data.Author: Bahcivan
data.Title: Efficacy of New Mindfulness-Based Swinging Technique Intervention: A Pilot Randomised Controlled Trial Among Women With Breast Cancer
data.Overall effect: Outcomes post-treatment showed significant higher-improvement in IG in all the assessed-measurements

data.Author: Balban
data.Title: Brief structured respiration practices enhance mood and reduce physiological arousal
data.Type of breathing practice: Cyclic Sighing, Box breathing, Cyclic hyperventilation
data.Primary Outcome of interest: improvement in mood and anxiety reduced physicological arousal (respiratory rate, heart rate, heart rate variability)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Anxiety/depression, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Using a mixed-effects model, we show that breathwork, especially the exhale-focused cyclic sighing, produces greater improvement in mood (p < 0.05) and reduction in respiratory rate (p < 0.05) compared with mindfulness meditation. Daily 5-min cyclic sighing has promise as an effective stress management exercise.

data.Author: Rosengård-Bärlund
data.Title: Deep breathing improves blunted baroreflex sensitivity even after 30 years of type 1 diabetes
data.Population category (students, general,: Long duration diabetic patients & general short duration diabetic patients
data.Type of breathing practice: Controlled breathing (15 breaths/min) + slow deep breathing (6 breaths/min)
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min of controlled breathing + 1 min of deep breathing
data.Primary Outcome of interest: BRS obtained from autonomic function parameters (HR, blood pressure, RR interval etc.)
data.Overall effect: Patients with type 1 diabeteshave a blunted BRS that in the majority of patients can be restored by slow breathing, irrespective of disease duration

data.Author: Bates
data.Title: Resonance-Paced Breathing Alters Neural Response to Visual Cues: Proof-of-Concept for a Neuroscience-Informed Adjunct to Addiction Treatments
data.Overall effect: Following resonance breathing, activation in brain regions involved in visual processing of cues was reduced, while activation in brain areas implicated in behavioral control, internally directed cognition, and brain–body integration was increased.

data.Author: Bayley
data.Title: Randomised clinical non-inferiority trial of breathing-based meditation and cognitive processing therapy for symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder in military veterans
data.Pop Condition: Mental Health Disorders, Patients with other diseases
data.Overall effect: SKY is significantly noninferior

data.Author: Bellissimo
data.Title: The Effects of Fast and Slow Yoga Breathing on Cerebral and Central Hemodynamics
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Central hemodynamics (HR, SV, and cardiac output [CO])
data.Overall effect: Kapalabhati pranayama may be an effective yoga breathing technique for eliciting cerebral brain oxygenation indicated by increased Hbdif. No significant outcomes observed for Sukha pranayama.

data.Author: Bertisch
data.Title: Slow Yogic Breathing and Long-Term Cardiac Autonomic Adaptations: A Pilot Study
data.Journal: Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine
data.Population: Long-term practioners of slow yogic breathing (at least 5 years)
data.Type of breathing practice: Paced breathing (0.25 Hz) + yogic slow breathing
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min of paced breathing + 10 min of slow yogic breathing
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Cardiac vagal outflow measured by respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA)
data.Overall effect: Although RSA was higher in practitioners compared to controls at rest, RSA did not differ between groups during paced breathing. RSA was higher during yogic breathing than during paced breathing, but did not differ compared to unpaced breathing.

data.Author: Bhavanani
data.Title:
Immediate Effect of Sukha Pranayama on
Cardiovascular Variables in Patients of Hypertension
data.Population category (students, general,: Patients in the Yoga Out Patient Department
data.Overall effect: Sukha pranayama significantly reduced heart rate and blood pressure

data.Author: Brazier
data.Title: Evaluating a yogic breathing and meditation intervention for individuals living with HIV/AIDS
data.Duration of intervention/study: 15 days in residence + 12 once a week follow up sessions
data.Type of breathing practice: 3 types of breathing excercises including SKY
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: MOS-HIV Health Survey, Daily Stres Intventory
data.Overall effect: Positive changes in well-being on the MHI and the MOS, primarily seen immediatly following the program. DSI indicated an increase in experience and impact of stress over time for intervention group post-program.

data.Author: Chandla
data.Title: Effect of short-term practice of pranayamic breathing exercises on cognition, anxiety, general well being and heart rate variability
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cognition, Anxiety/depression, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect: Highly significant increase in high frequency and significant decrease in low frequency aspects of HRV for pranayam group. Highly significant improvement in cognition, general well-being, and anxiety for pranayam group. Well-being significantly improved for suryanamaskar group.

data.Author: Chandra
data.Title: Effect of Sudarshan Kriya (meditation) on gamma, alpha, and theta rhythm during working memory task
data.Overall effect: SKY promoted the efficient use of energy and power spectral density (PSD) for different brain rhythms in the desired locations as depicted by the gamma (F8 channel), alpha, and theta 2 (F7 and FC5) bands, with higher scores in the experimental group

data.Author: Alaguveni
data.Title: Effect of Deep Breathing Exercise on Heart Rate Variability of Different Age Groups
data.Journal: Journal of Research in Medical and Dental Science
data.Primary Outcome of interest: HRV, Autonomic function tests (isometric handgrip test, cold pressor test, ortho static standing test, HRV during deep breathing test)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect: Observed a statistically insignificant decrease in SBP, DBP and basal HR, in both the groups after practicing deep breathing exercise for 6 months indicating sympathetic inhibition. The effect of slow deep breathing exercise was more in the age group of 18 to 25 years than in the age group of 26 to 35 years

data.Author: Dinesh
data.Title: Effect of 12 weeks of slow breathing exercise practice on anthropometric parameters in healthy volunteers
data.Journal: National Journal of Physiology, Pharmacy and Pharmacology
data.Overall effect: After intervention, BMI was decreased significantly in the study group. WHR was not significantly affected.

data.Author: Downey
data.Title: The effects of deep breathing training on pain management in the emergency department
data.Population: Patients presenting to ED with pain as chief complaint
data.Overall effect: No significant difference between those who received the deep breathing education and those that did not with regards to postmedication pain levels, though DBE was seen as useful by the majority of patients

data.Author: D'Silva
data.Title: Effectiveness of deep breathing exercise (DBE) on the heart rate variability, BP, anxiety & depression of patients with coronary artery disease
data.Journal: Nitte University Journal of Health Science
data.Overall effect:
DBE was found to be effective in reducing anxiety and diastolic BP of clients with CAD. But there was no significant
reduction in HR, SBP and depression after the intervention.

data.Author: Ghati
data.Title: A randomized trial of the immediate effect of bee-humming breathing exercise on blood pressure and heart rate variability in patients with essential hypertension
data.Overall effect: No signifcant change in blood pressure, significant increase in the HF power, and decrease in the LF power

data.Author: Ghorashi
data.Title: The effects of yoga‑based breathing techniques and meditation on outpatients’ symptoms of COVID‑19 and anxiety scores
data.Journal: Journal of Nursing and Midwifery Sciences
data.Type of breathing practice: Pranayama (Nadi Shodhan, Kapalbhati, Ujjayi, and Anulom Vilom etc)
data.Breathing Category: Nadi Shodhan Pranayama, Kapalabhati Breathing, Ujjayi Breathing
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
COVID-19 symptom severity, headache,
myalgia, and anxiety scores
data.Overall effect: Intervention group had significantly lower scores of headache, myalgia, anxiety, severity of cough, dyspnea, and weakness than the control group

data.Author: Goldstein
data.Title: Improvements in well-being and cardiac metrics of stress following a yogic breathing workshop: Randomized controlled trial with active comparison
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Domains of stress (psychological and physiological), sleep, and social connectedness
data.Primary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Sleep related/fatigue
data.Overall effect:
SKY demonstrated greater improvements on a number of self-report measures relative to WOW, including perceived stress, sleep, social connectedness, distress, anxiety, depression, conscientiousness, self-esteem, and life satisfaction. Both groups improved in terms of heart rate measures of
stress reactivity.

data.Author: Schulz-Heik
data.Title: Valued living among veterans in breath-based meditation treatment or cognitive processing therapy for posttraumatic stress disorder: Exploratory outcome of a randomized controlled trial
data.Journal: Global Advances in Health and Medicine
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: PTSD checklist-civilian version, Beck Depression Inventory II, Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview
data.Overall effect: Participants in the CPT group improved from baseline to end of treatment in both VQ-Progress (d=0.55, p=0.02) and VQ–Obstruction (d=-0.51, p=0.03), while the SKY group did not improve on either subscale. However, differences between treatments were not statistically significant. Participants reporting less valued living and more depression symptoms at baseline reported greater improvements in valued living following treatment

data.Author: Jurek
data.Title: The effects of slow deep breathing on microvascular and autonomic function and symptoms in adults with irritable bowel syndrome: A pilot study
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Microvascular endothelial function, HRV, HRR, IBS symptoms
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Gastrointestinal Function
data.Overall effect: Preliminary findings suggest an improvement in microvascular endothelial function. However, HRV, HRR, and IBS-SS scores were unaltered

data.Author: Kaneko
data.Title: Effects of Slow Breathing Exercise in Chronic Kidney Disease Patients
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Autonomic nervous parameters (HR, BP, HRV, RR, skin tempterature, skin blood flow)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect:
After SBE, respiratory rate and LF/HF ratio decreased, diastolic blood pressure tended to decrease, and HF and
skin temperature tended to increase. SBE has the potential to improve autonomic nervous imbalance in CKD patients.

data.Author: Katzman
data.Title: A multicomponent yoga-based, breath intervention program as an adjunctive treatment in patients suffering from generalized anxiety disorder with or without comorbidities
data.Overall effect: Significant reductions occurred in the pre- and post-intervention mean HAM-A total score and psychic subscale

data.Author: Kopanska
data.Title: Quantitative electroencephalography interpretation of human brain activity after COVID-19 before and after Sudarshan Kriya Yoga
data.Population: Patients who had COVID-19 2 months prior
data.Overall effect: SKY significantly affects brain activity by changing the amplitude of emitted brain waves, thereby improving parameters that translate into the improvement of cognitive abilities such as concentration and memory

data.Author: Kupershmidt
data.Title: Definition of a Yoga Breathing (Pranayama) Protocol That Improves Lung Function
data.Type of breathing practice: 3 pranayama techniques (Dirga Svasam, Kappala Bhati, Nadhi Suddhi)
data.Breathing Category: Kapalabhati Breathing, Nadi Shodhan Pranayama, Non-specified Pranayama
data.Overall effect: FEV1 and PEF values significantly increased in intervention group Differences in FEV1 were not detected in the control group. Differences in PEF were detected in both groups, although the effect was much smaller in the control than in the intervention group

data.Author: Laborde
data.Title: The effect of slow-paced breathing on stress management in adolescents with intellectual disability
data.Overall effect: During cognitive stress, vagal tone was higher in the slow-paced breathing condition compared with the audiobook condition, reflecting better stress management

data.Author: Laborde
data.Title: The Influence of Slow-Paced Breathing on Executive Function
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Executive function tasks (Inhibition task, Working Memory, Cognitive Flexibility)
data.Overall effect: Performance on executive function tasks was better after slow-paced breathing compared to control, with higher scores observed for Stroop interference accuracy, automated operation span score, and perseverative errors, but not Stroop interference reaction times. This difference in executive function between experimental conditions was not mediated by cardiac vagal activity

data.Author: Liu
data.Title: Slow, deep breathing intervention improved symptoms and altered rectal sensitivity in patients with constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect: 6-week SDB intervention improved symptoms and altered rectal sensation in IBS-C patients and enhanced vagal activity, indicating the effect of SDB on IBS-C may be due to mechanisms involving autonomic responses

data.Author: Madanmohan
data.Title: Effect of slow and fast pranayams on reaction time and cardiorespiratory variables
data.Type of breathing practice: Slow breathing savitri pranayam, fast breathing bhastrika pranayam
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Visual reaction time (VRT), auditory reaction time (ART), maximum expiratory pressure (MEP) and maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Blood pressure (BP), heart rate (HR), double product (Do P) and rate-pressure product (RPP)
data.Overall effect: Savitri pranayam produced a significant increase in respiratory pressures and respiratory endurance. In both the groups, there was an appreciable but statistically insignificant shortening of reaction time. Heart rate, ratepressure product and double product decreased in savitri pranayam group but increased significantly in bhastrika group

data.Author: Madden
data.Title: Effects of mental state on heart rate and blood pressure variability in men and women
data.Type of breathing practice: Paced breathing at spontaneous breathing pace
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart rate variability (HRV), systolic blood pressure variability (BPV) and arterial baroreflex function
data.Overall effect: Paced breathing at the spontaneous frequency does not alter HRV, BPV, or spontaneous baroreflex function as compared to normal (spontaneous) breathing conditions.

data.Author: Magnon
data.Title: Benefits from one session of deep and slow breathing on vagal tone and anxiety in young and older adults
data.Age: Young (mean 19.56 years) and older (mean 65.86 years) adults
data.Overall effect: 1) DSB seems to reduce anxiety level and increase vagal outfow (which are negatively correlated with each other) in both young and older adults; 2) DSB could have a greater efect on parasympathetic activity in older adults

data.Author: Misra
data.Title: Take a deep breath: A randomized control trial of Pranayama breathing on uncontrolled hypertension
data.Type of breathing practice: Pranayama (bellow breathing, rapid exhalations, alternate nostril breathing, bumblebee breathing, om singing)
data.Breathing Category: Bhastrika (Bellows Breath), Alternate Nostril Breathing, Bhramari (Bee-Humming Breath), Non-specified Pranayama
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Systolic and diastolic blood pressure measurements
data.Overall effect: Yogic breathing exercises was significantly associated with _x0001_5 mm Hg reduction in systolic blood pressure among uncontrolled hypertensive patients. . DVD/YouTube instruction did just as well as in-class instruction group.

data.Author: Naik
data.Title: Effect of Modified Slow Breathing Exercise on Perceived Stress and Basal Cardiovascular Parameters
data.Type of breathing practice: Slow deep breathing (modified anuloma viloma pranayama)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Cardiovascular parameters (HR, SBP, DBP), percieved stress
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect: Modified slow breathing exercise reduced perceived stress and improved the cardiovascular parameters

data.Author: Novaes
data.Title: Effects of Yoga Respiratory Practice (Bhastrika pranayama) on Anxiety, Affect, and Brain Functional Connectivity and Activity: A Randomized Controlled Trial
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Anxiety, affect, brain functional connectivity and activity involved with emotional processing
data.Overall effect: Pranayama significantly decreased states of anxiety and negative affect. The practice of pranayama also modulated the activity of brain regions involved in emotional processing, particularly the amygdala, anterior cingulate, anterior insula, and prefrontal cortex

data.Author: Patil
data.Title: EFFECTS OF SUDARSHAN KRIYA ON STRESS REDUCTION IN GENERAL POPULATION
data.Journal: JOURNAL OF EVOLUTION OF MEDICAL AND DENTAL SCIENCES
data.Population: Adults practicing SK for more than 6 months
data.Population category (students, general,: Regular practitioners of SK for >6 months
data.Control: Age-matched controls using other Stress Releasing Measure (SRM)
data.Overall effect: SK relieves stress in general population in a very significant manner when compared with other stress releasing measures

data.Author: Pradhan
data.Title: Deep Breathing Exercise and Quality of sleep: An Experimental study among Geriatrics
data.Journal: European Journal of Molecular & Clinical Medicine
data.Overall effect: Geriatrics who received the intervention show the level of sleep quality is enhanced compared to control

data.Author: Rajesh
data.Title: Effect of Bhramari Pranayama on response inhibition: Evidence from the stop signal task
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Probability of responding on stop signal trials, P (rs) and mean RT to go stimuli
data.Overall effect: Bhpr enhanced response inhibition and cognitive control in nonclinical participants, with more significant effects for Bhpr group

data.Author: Saxena
data.Title: The effect of various breathing exercises (pranayama) in patients with bronchial asthma of mild to moderate severity
data.Population: Patients with bronchial asthma (mild to moderate severity)
data.Type of breathing practice: Pranayama (deep breathing, Sasankasana, Anuloma viloma, Bhramari, Omkara)
data.Breathing Category: Slow Deep Breathing, Nadi Shodhan Pranayama, Bhramari (Bee-Humming Breath), Non-specified Pranayama
data.Overall effect: After 12 weeks there was significant improvement in symptoms and lung functions in intervention group

data.Author: Seppala
data.Title: Promoting mental health and psychological thriving in university students: a randomized controlled trial of three well-being interventions
data.Type of breathing practice: SKY, EI (Foundations of Emotional Intelligence), MBSR (Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Mental health, psychological thriving, health outcomes (physical health and sleep)
data.Primary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Sleep related/fatigue
data.Overall effect: Significant improvements in the SKY group were depression, mental health, stress, mindfulness, positive affect, and social connectedness

data.Author: Seppala
data.Title: Breathing-Based Meditation Decreases Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Symptoms in U.S. Military Veterans: A Randomized Controlled Longitudinal Study
data.Population: Male veterans with service in Afghanistan or Iraq
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Self-reported anxiety and depression, psychophysiological measures of startle response,and respiration rates
data.Overall effect: The active group showed reductions in PTSD scores, anxiety symptoms, and respiration rate, but the control group did not. Reductions in startle correlated with reductions in hyperarousal symptoms immediately postintervention and at 1-year follow-up

data.Author: Jain Shrimal
data.Title: Efficacy of Integrated Tele-Yoga Intervention on Physiological and Psychological Variables in Asymptomatic COVID-19 Positive Patients: A Confirmatory Randomized Control Trial
data.Type of breathing practice: Hands in and out breathing, Hands stretch breathing, Abdominal breathing, Bhrastrika pranayama, Nadi shodhana pranayama
data.Breathing Category: Bhastrika (Bellows Breath), Nadi Shodhan Pranayama, Non-specified Pranayama
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Oxygen saturation, heart rate, respiratory rate, and blood pressure
data.Primary Outcome Category: Respiratory Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Stress, COVID-19 peritraumatic distress, and mindfulness
data.Overall effect: Physiological and psychological variables which included cxygen saturation, Heart rate, Respiratory rate, Systolic blood pressure, Diastolic blood pressure, Visual Analog Scale for stress, COVID-19 Peritraumatic Distress Index , and State Mindful Attention Awareness Scale showed significant changes in the experimental group compared to control group

data.Author: Sundaram
data.Title: Slow breathing training on cardio-respiratory control and exercise capacity in persons with essential hypertension -- a randomized controlled trial
data.Journal: Indian Journal of Physiotherapy & Occupational Therapy
data.Population category (students, general,: Patients at outpatient tertiary care hospital
data.Primary Outcome of interest: 6 minute walk test, Heart rate, Blood pressure, and Respiratory rate
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Physical Fitness, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Slow breathing training significantly improves cardiorespiratory control but it fails to improve the exercise capacity in patients with essential hypertension

data.Author: Goshvarpour
data.Title: Do meditators and non-meditators have different HRV dynamics?
data.Duration of intervention/study:
KYM: Single session (1 hour)
CCM: Most of meditators started Chinese Chi meditation (CCM) practice for about 1–3 months before the exper-
iment. Intervention is single session (about 1 hour).
data.Control: Spontaneous normal breathing (SNB) or metronomic breathing (MB)
data.Overall effect:
The HRV dynamics were significantly different in meditators (KYM and CCM) and non-meditator.
The results showed the greatest discrepancies in the lagged Poincare indices for KYM and CCM. Compared to SNB, an enhancement in the log energy entropy and a reduction in the LZ and other entro-pies were concluded during KYM and CCM practices. Using support vector
machine, HRV dynamics were classified with average accuracies of 99.14 and 98.2% and average sensitivities of 99.87 and 99.57% for pre-KYM and during KYM, respectively.

data.Author: Grieco
data.Title: Acute effect of breathing exercises on heart rate variability in type 2 diabetes: a pilot study
data.Population: Type 2 diabetes mellitus(T2D) vs. normoglycemic population(CON)
data.Control: Same breathing practice as intervention group
data.Overall effect: Between-groups comparisons revealed significant reductions in all measures of HRV at nearly all time points in T2D compared to CON. Within-group comparison demonstrated no significant effect of UNB or PB on HRV in CON. In the T2D group, however, left UNB significantly reduced mean HR ( - 1.2 bpm, p < 0.05) as well as TP ( p < 0.05).

data.Author: Gupta
data.Title: Positive Psychological Changes at High Altitude Shown by the Low Landers after the Yoga Interventionâ€”Sudarshan Kriya Yoga (SKY)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: The Oxford Happiness Questionnaier, Height, weight, BMI, waist circumference, hip circumference, acute mountain sickness, SpO2, blood pressure, LDL, HDL. VLDL
data.Primary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Physical Measurements and Anthropometric Parameters, Biochemical and Metabolic Function
data.Overall effect:
Oxford Happiness Questionnaire (OHQ) showed a significant positive result in the SKY group with p-value ≤ .001, whereas it is nonsignificant in the control group. Anthropometric and physiological changes in the intervention group showed 
significant effects on weight, BMI, waist circumference, hip circumference, and blood pressure; with no significant effect in the control group

data.Author: Hayama
data.Title: The effects of deep breathing on 'tension-anxiety' and fatigue in cancer patients undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy
data.Duration of intervention/study: 1 day before the first chemotherapy and 3 days during the first chemotherapy cycle
data.Population:
Newly diagnosed gynaecological
cancer patients hoping to be cured by adjuvant chemotherapy
data.Population category (students, general,: Patients in an obstetrics and gynaecology inpatient unit
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 40 min for a day of pre-chemotherapy, and the second, fourth, and sixth days of post-chemotherapy
data.Primary Outcome of interest: The Profile of Mood States (POMS), The Cancer Fatigue Scale (CFS)
data.Primary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Sleep related/fatigue
data.Overall effect: Tensione anxiety and fatigue of the intervention group were relieved more than those of the control group

data.Author: Hayano
data.Title: Effects of respiratory interval on vagal modulation of heart rate
data.Duration of intervention/study: 5 Sessions (single session(4 min of paced breathing ＋ 1 min of rest) x 5)
data.Control: Spontaneous breathing and either drug treatment (control or propranolol)
data.Overall effect:
The effect of paced breathing and respiratory interval on the spectral components of HRV are not mediated
by the changes in mean cardiac vagal tone and support the hypothesis that increased respiratory interval amplifies the
respiratory-related vagal modulation of heart rate.

data.Author: Helen
data.Title: Impact of respiration on cardiovascular coupling using Granger causality analysis in healthy subjects
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Electrocardiogram(RR), arterial blood pressure(SBP), and respiration(RESP)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing has significant impact on cardiovascular coupling.

data.Author: Herakova
data.Title: Effect of respiratory pattern on automated clinical blood pressure measurement: an observational study with normotensive subjects
data.Population category (students, general,:
Individuals with SBP < 140 mmHg and
DBP < 90 mmHg
data.Overall effect: The measured automated BPs decreased by different amounts with all the four deep breathing patterns, which recovered back quickly after these single short-term interventions.

data.Author: Hilz
data.Title: Metronomic breathing shows altered parasympathetic baroreflex function in untreated Fabry patients and baroreflex improvement after enzyme replacement therapy(ERT)
data.Condition: Homogeneous, mild stage of Fabry disease before and after enzyme replacement therapy
data.Population category (students, general,: Patients(Intervention group), age-matched healthy volunteers(Control group)
data.Age: Intervention group(28±8 years), Control group(29±9 years)
data.Control: Recieved placebo for 5 months and then joined biweekly ERT
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: In untreated Fabry patients, MDB uncovers impaired BRS. After 18 or 23 months of ERT, MDB-induced BRS increase is similar in Fabry patients and controls, demonstrating that ERT not only restores sympathetic but also parasympathetic baroreflex activation.

data.Author: Hinterberger
data.Title: The brain's resonance with breathing-decelerated breathing synchronizes heart rate and slow cortical potentials
data.Population: 38 Participants in one session of paced breathing
data.Condition:
3 participants reported slight respiratory tract infection and 3 suffered from
migraine. 4 participants were smokers and 14 were experienced in meditation.
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart rate variability (HRV), 64-channel electroencephalogram(EEG) and slow cortical potentials(SCPs)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect:
Decelerated breathing at a rate of 6 cycles/min has a strong in
fluence on the slow cortical potentials(SCPs) of the brain

data.Author: Hoffmann
data.Title: Keeping the pace: The effect of slow-paced breathing on error monitoring
data.Duration of intervention/study: Intervention (15 min × 2 times) + HRV resting measurement (5 min × 2 times)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Breathing rate (BR), high-frequency heart rate variability (HF-HRV), and EEG
data.Primary Outcome Category: Respiratory Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect: The error negativity or error-related negativity was increased following slow-paced breathing compared to a passive control condition. Furthermore, behavioral results indicate that response variability decreased in the slow-paced breathing condition whereas overall performance remained constant.

data.Author: Horsman
data.Title: Interactions between breathing rate and low-frequency fluctuations in blood pressure and cardiac intervals
data.Condition:
Nonsmokers and free from respiratory, cardiovascular, neurological,
and endocrine disease.
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Systolic arterial blood pressure
(SAP) power spectral density (PSD) and cardiac
period (R-R interval), and baroreflex sensitivity 
(BRS)
data.Overall effect: Increases in spectral indices of BRS reflect the frequency dependence of the baroreflex and are not due to slow breathing per se.

data.Author: Hotho
data.Title: Unexpected Cardiovascular Oscillations at 0.1Â Hz During Slow Speech Guided Breathing (OM Chanting) at 0.05Â Hz
data.Condition:
Healthy with no history of cardiovascular diseases, especially 
no hypo- or hypertension
data.Population category (students, general,: Professional speech and drama therapy practitioners
data.Type of breathing practice:
Slow speech guided breathing (OM chanting) at 3
respiratory cpm (0.05 Hz)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart period (RR), respiration (RESP) and systolic blood pressure (SBP)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: During OM chanting synchronisation among the oscillations of RR, SBP and RESP was significantly increased compared to rest. Furthermore, OM chanting at breathing frequencies between 0.046 and 0.057 Hz resulted in 0.1 Hz oscillations in RR and SBP.

data.Author: Hsu
data.Title: Slow-paced inspiration regularizes alpha phase dynamics in the human brain
data.Condition: Without previous neurological or psychiatric history
data.Overall effect: Slow-paced relative to normal-paced inspiration could organize the timing of alpha rhythmic activities across breathing cycles in a structured manner over widespread brain areas.

data.Author: Hunt
data.Title: Mindful Versus Diaphragmatic Breathing: Spirituality Moderates the Impact on Heart Rate Variability
data.Population:
Undergraduate students recruited from
psychology courses
data.Type of breathing practice: Mindful breathing vs deep diaphragmatic breathing
data.Control: No control group (Mindful breathing or deep diaphragmatic breathing groups)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Respiration rate, tidal volume and heart rate variability (HRV)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Respiratory Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: Both types of training (mindful and diaphragmatic breathing exercises) resulted in lower respiration rate and higher tidal volume over baseline, but only diaphragmatic breathing resulted in significant increases in HRV. Spirituality moderated the impact, such that spiritual people benefited equally from both types of breathing training, but less spiritual people benefited more from diaphragmatic breathing than from mindful breathing.

data.Author: Hunt
data.Title: Positive Effects of Diaphragmatic Breathing on Physiological Stress Reactivity in Varsity Athletes
data.Duration of intervention/study: 5 min (Paced breathing (6 breaths/min) + 10 min (Deep diaphragmatic breathing or Progressive muscle relaxation) +5 min (Paced breathing (6 breaths/min)
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min (Paced breathing (6 breaths/min) + 10 min (Deep diaphragmatic breathing or Progressive muscle relaxation) +5 min (Paced breathing (6 breaths/min)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Respiration rate, tidal volume, heart rate, and HRV
data.Primary Outcome Category: Respiratory Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: Deep diaphragmatic breathing(DB) resulted in significantly higher tidal volume compared to Progressive muscle relaxation(PMR) and paced breathing. DB also resulted in lower heart rate than PMR. Finally, DB resulted in significantly higher HRV than PMR,but not compared to simple paced breathing. DB and PMR groups reported feeling significantly morerelaxed after the intervention than after paced breathing. The DB group reported a trend toward greater relaxation than the PMR group.

data.Author: Hunter
data.Title: Device-guided slow breathing alters postprandial oxidative stress in young adult males: a randomized sham-controlled crossover trial
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 2 min breathing exercise every 15 min during 4 hours
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Superoxide dismutase (SOD), thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS), and flow-mediated dilation (FMD)
data.Overall effect: The total area under the curve (AUC) for superoxide dismutase was significantly lower during slow deep breathing compared to the sham breathing condition (p < 0.01). No differences were observed in thiobarbituric acid reactive substances AUC (p =0.538).

data.Author: Im
data.Title: Kouksundo, a traditional Korean mind-body practice, regulates oxidative stress profiles and stress hormones
data.Population: 57 Kouksundo training members at a Kouksundo training center
data.Condition: 30 healthy subjects and 27 unhealthy subjects who had at least one disorder
data.Pop Condition: Healthy Individuals, Patients with other diseases
data.Duration of breathing exercise: Kouksundo training (25 min for warm-up, 45 min for deep-breathing meditation, and 20 min for cool-down)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Oxidant markers, anti-oxidant markers, and stress hormones
data.Overall effect: Kouksundo significantly reduced serum levels of three oxidants and stress hormones. Additionally, Kouksundo significantly altered serum levels of anti-oxidants.

data.Author: Iskra
data.Title: Slow-paced breathing: influence of inhalation / exhalation ratio and of respiratory pauses on cardiac vagal activity
data.Journal: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF SPORT AND EXERCISE PSYCHOLOGY
data.Condition: Self-reported without cardiovascular diseases and other chronic diseases
data.Population category (students, general,: Individuals regularly engaging in sport training
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min × 6 times (different inhalation/exhalation ratios and with or without respiratory pauses (0.4 s))
data.Primary Outcome of interest: The root mean square of successive differences
data.Overall effect: The root mean square of successive differences (RMSSD), a marker of cardiac vagal activity, was higher when exhalation was longer than inhalation. The presence of a brief (0.4 s) post-inhalation and post-exhalation respiratory pause did not further influence RMSSD.

data.Author: Jafari
data.Title: Can Slow Deep Breathing Reduce Pain? An Experimental Study Exploring Mechanisms
data.Overall effect: Compared to unpaced breathing, participants reported less intense pain during each of the 3 instructed breathing patterns (paced breathing (PB) at the participant’s spontaneous breathing frequency, SDB at 6 breaths per minute with a high inspiration/expiration ratio (SDB-H), and SDB at 6 breaths per minute with a low inspiration/expiration ratio (SDB-L)). Among the instructed breathing patterns, pain did not differ between PB and SDB-H, and SDB-L attenuated pain more than the PB and SDB-H patterns.

data.Author: Jansang
data.Title: Effects of Pursed-Lip Breathing Exercise Using Windmill Toy on Lung Function and Respiratory Muscle Strength in the Elderly
data.Condition: Those who are normal mobility and independent self-care without history of chronic lung disease
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Shortness of breath scores, the ratio of force vital capacity (FVC), forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV) and maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP)
data.Overall effect: Shortness of breath scores, the ratio of force vital capacity (FVC), forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV), and maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP) were significantly increased (all p<0.05) in the PBE group compared to control and DBE groups at weeks 12. However, no significant differences in maximum expiratory pressure (MEP) were observed in all three groups.

data.Author: Jarrah
data.Title: The effect of slow deep breathing relaxation exercise on pain levels during and post chest tube removal after coronary artery bypass graft surgery
data.Population: Post coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery patients
data.Population category (students, general,: Patients in a cardiac intensive care unit in Jordan’s major referral heart institute
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Heart rate (HR), blood pressure (BP), respiratory rate (RR), and oxygen saturation (SpO2)
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: The control and intervention group of patients showed that there was a statistically significant decline in their pain level across time for both groups (P < 0.01) respectively. The intervention group had significantly lower pain levels than the control group at 5-min post chest tube removal (CTR) (P < 0.01) and 15-min post CTR (P < 0.01).

data.Author: JÃ¡uregui-Renaud
data.Title: Paced breathing can prevent vasovagal syncope during head-up tilt testing
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min of spontaneous breatihg + 5 min of pased breathing
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart rate, Systolic blood pressure, LF component of HRV, and HF component of HRV
data.Overall effect: During the head-up tilt test (HUT) with paced breathing, only one of the patients developed bradycardia, hypertension and syncope. Compared with HUT with spontaneous breathing, HUT with paced breathing increased heart rate significantly in the first minutes of tilt (p< 0.05).

data.Author: Jokerst
data.Title: Slow deep breathing prevents the development of tachygastria and symptoms of motion sickness
data.Control:
(1)counting breath group (subjects were asked to count their breaths and asked for the count every 
3 min), (2)control group (breathed normally)
data.Overall effect: Percent tachygastria increased during rotation for the Counting Breaths group and the Control group, but remained the same as baseline for the Slow Deep Breathing group. The Slow Deep Breathing group (5.3) reported significantly fewer symptoms than the Counting Breaths group (9.0), but not the Control group (7.8).

data.Author: Jones
data.Title: Slow breathing training reduces resting blood pressure and the pressure responses to exercise
data.Type of breathing practice: (1) unloaded slow breathing ((10 s/breath) (2) slow breathing against an inspiratory load of 20 cm H2O
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Blood pressure, heart rate, handgrip pressor test, and resting systolic
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Physical Fitness
data.Overall effect: After training, there was both a smaller pressor response to handgrip exercise and a more rapid recovery of resting systolic (sBP) and heart rate (HR) compared to pre-training. There were no changes in the Controls and no differences between the Unloaded and Loaded groups. Combining the two training groups, the sBP response to handgrip exercise after training was reduced by 10 mm Hg and HR by 5 bpm, all p<0.05.

data.Author: Joseph
data.Title: Slow breathing improves arterial baroreflex sensitivity and decreases blood pressure in essential hypertension
data.Population:
Exposed; patients with essential hypertension (untreated or after
2-week pharmacological washout). Control; healthy subjects
data.Type of breathing practice: Slow breathing (6 breaths/min) and controlled breathing (15 breaths/min)
data.Control: Same breathing exercise between exposed and control groups
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min of spontaneous breathing + 2 min of slow breathing (6 breaths/min) + 2 min of fast breathing (15 breaths/min)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Blood pressure, RR interval, respiration, end-tidal CO2 (CO2-et), and arterial baroreflex sensitivity
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Slow breathing reduces blood pressure and enhances baroreflex sensitivity in hypertensive patients.

data.Author: Joshi
data.Title: Stress monitoring through non-invasive instrumental analysis of skin conductivity
data.Overall effect: The experimental group (yogic breathing group) reported reduction in mean value in skin conductivity after deep breathing as compared to the control group, and this was significant (p < 0.01 and p < 0.05).

data.Author: Joshi
data.Title: Stress management through regulation of blood pressure among college students
data.Condition: Those who reported high mental stress
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) and
Diastolic Blood Pressure (DBP)
data.Overall effect: The DBP is recorded as 87.27 before the Deep Breathing Technique Drill and 79.89 after the Deep Breathing Technique drill. SBP was 128.82 before the DBT drill and 121.03 after the drill.

data.Author: Joshi
data.Title: A Nonrandomized Non-Naive Comparative Study of the Effects of Kapalabhati and Breath Awareness on Event-Related Potentials in Trained Yoga Practitioners
data.Journal: JOURNAL OF ALTERNATIVE AND COMPLEMENTARY MEDICINE
data.Population category (students, general,: Adults who recieve yoga training in yoga center
data.Type of breathing practice: High-frequency yoga breathing vs Breath awareness
data.Overall effect: The P300 peak latency decreased after High-frequency yoga breathing and the P300 peak amplitude increased after breath awareness.

data.Author: Kanchibhotla
data.Title: Effectiveness of a Comprehensive Yoga Program on Convicted Extremist Offenders
data.Population: United Liberation Front of Assam militants
data.Population category (students, general,: United Liberation Front of Assam militants selected immediately after surrender of arms in the year 2012 from all over northeast region of India
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Buss Perry questionnaire, WHOQOL‑BREF, and Satisfaction with 
Life Scale
data.Overall effect: SKY and Meditation resulted in a statistically significant reduction in aggression, quality of life, and life satisfaction.

data.Author: Kanchibhotla
data.Title: Association of yogic breathing with perceived stress and conception of strengths and difficulties in teenagers
data.Population category (students, general,: Experimental group: those who practiced SKY daily. Control; those who did not practice any form of yoga or meditation
data.Duration of breathing exercise: Started 4-day workshop (25 min/day). After that, daily SKY practices conducted for a year
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Child Perceived Stress scale (C-PSS) and Strength and Difficulty 
questionnaire (SDQ)
data.Overall effect:
The SKY group reported lower stress scores than the control group. Females from the SKY group scored lower on emotional problems sub-scale compared to females from control group. Both boys and girls in the SKY group improved peer
to peer interaction.

data.Author: Keptner
data.Title: Effectiveness of anxiety reduction interventions on test anxiety: A comparison of four techniques incorporating sensory modulation
data.Control: Adapted dive reflex, Weighted item on lap, or progressive muscle relaxation
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Beck Anxiety Inventory(BAI), Westfield Test Anxiety Scale, StateTrait Anxiety Inventory(STAI), and Subjective Unit of Distress Scale (SUDS)
data.Overall effect: All four interventions (deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, an adapted dive reflex, and use of a weighted lap object) significantly reduced state anxiety. The sensory-based interventions of adapted dive reflex and weighted lap object appeared to have a longer duration of impact than the traditional interventions of deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation.

data.Author: Khan
data.Title: Management of myofascial pain dysfunction syndrome with meditation and yoga: Healing through natural therapy
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Pain, mouth opening, mandibular deviation, inflammation, swelling, clicking, occlusion, and psychologic evaluation
data.Primary Outcome Category: Pain Perception, Muscular Function, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect: Posttreatment pain and inflammation improved both in the control group and Experimental A group, but statistically it is highly significant in the Experimental A group. Furthermore, it is effective immediately as well as for a long period in Experimental A group. Improvement in mouth opening was statistically highly significant in control group but not in the experimental groups. Posttreatment anxiety and stress status was improved with statistically highly significant result in the Experimental A and B. The posttreatment depression status along with mandibular deviation, swelling, clicking, and occlusion has not improved significantly in any of the groups.

data.Author: Khng
data.Title: A better state-of-mind: deep breathing reduces state anxiety and enhances test performance through regulating test cognitions in children
data.Population category (students, general,: Primary fifth grade students from four elementary schools
data.Control: Rested with no specified activity during breaking time
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Trait test anxiety, state test anxiety, math computational test performance, the revised Children’s Cognitive Assessment Questionnaire, and Inhibitory-control-of-attention
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing reduces state anxiety in test-like situations, creating a better state-of-mind by enhancing the regulation of adaptive-maladaptive thoughts during the test, allowing for better performance.

data.Author: Khng
data.Title: Beyond BCI-Validating a wireless, consumer-grade EEG headset against a medical-grade system for evaluating EEG effects of a test anxiety intervention in school
data.Population category (students, general,: Right-handed Primary Five students (~Grade 5) from five local schools
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing may enhance attentional control on a neural level by modulating brain electrical activity on several frequencies.

data.Author: Kim
data.Title: The Effect of a Web-Based Deep Breathing App on Stress of Direct Care Workers: Uncontrolled Intervention Study
data.Population category (students, general,: Direct care workers who serve people with intellectual and developmental disabilities
data.Duration of breathing exercise: As many breathing cycles as participants desired
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Stress levels, and frequency and number of days the web-based app for breathing exercise
data.Overall effect: Among within-individual factors, a higher initial stress level and longer app use per occasion were significantly associated with stress reduction. Among between-individual factors, only race was associated with stress reduction.

data.Author: Klinsophon
data.Title: The Effect of Breathing Exercise on Nicotine Withdrawal Symptoms, Cigarette Cravings, and Affect
data.Condition:
Continuous smoker for at least 1 year who were of mild-to-moderate 
nicotine dependence level
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Nicotine withdrawal symptoms, cigarette cravings, affect, and heart rate variability
data.Primary Outcome Category: Anxiety/depression, General well-being/quality of life, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: Three-part breathing exercise resulted in lower negative affect scores relative to control condition and controlled deep breathing immediately after post intervention. Additionally, high-frequency heart rate variability score was significantly reduced throughout the 30-minute session.

data.Author: Komori
data.Title: Extreme prolongation of expiration breathing: Effects on electroencephalogram and autonomic nervous function
data.Population:
Individuals who practiced extreme prolongation of expiration
breathing (Okinaga)
data.Population category (students, general,:
Individuals who practiced extreme prolongation of expiration
breathing (Okinaga)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: ECG and EEG parameters (theta, alpha, and beta rythmns), and heart rate variability
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect: Theta and alpha 2 waves increased and beta waves decreased as Okinaga progressed. Parasympathetic dominance was observed as Okinaga progressed.

data.Author: Kondam
data.Title: Combined effects of pranayama and suryanamaskar on dynamic spirometric values in normal young subjects
data.Journal: National Journal of Physiology, Pharmacy and Pharmacology
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 30 min yoga + 30 min pranayama and/or suryanamaskar
data.Overall effect: The VC, FVC, FEV1, FEV3, FEV1/FVC, PEFR, and FEF25–75% values were highly significant in the pranayama group than the suryanamaskara group. All the above values were highly significant (p < 0.05) in the combined group of pranayama and suryanamaskara when compared to the other groups.

data.Author: Kondam
data.Title: The effect of yoga in improved cognitive functions in medical students: A comparative study
data.Journal: National Journal of Physiology, Pharmacy and Pharmacology
data.Control: Taking lecture on stress reduction, practice of meditation without any yoga instructions
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 30 min yoga + 30 min pranayama and/or suryanamaskar
data.Overall effect: Yogic breathing and yogic postures (suryanamaskar) has a significant effect on the reduction of anxiety level and improvement in cognitive functions of medical students.

data.Author: Kow
data.Title: The impact of music guided deep breathing exercise on blood pressure control - A participant blinded randomised controlled study
data.Overall effect: Both listening to music and deep breathing exercise were associated with a clinically significant reduction in systolic and diastolic Blood Pressure. However, blood pressure reduction between the two activities was not significant.

data.Author: Kozasa
data.Title: Evaluation of Siddha Samadhi yoga for anxiety and depression symptoms: A preliminary study
data.Primary Outcome of interest: State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, Beck Depression Inventory, Tension Feelings Self-evaluation Scales, and Well-being Self-evaluation Scale
data.Overall effect: A significant reduction in scores on anxiety, depression, and tension was found in yoga group, as well as an increase in well-being in comparison with che control group.

data.Author: Kozhevnikov
data.Title: Neurocognitive and somatic components of temperature increases during g-tummo meditation: legend and reality
data.Overall effect: Reliable increases in axillary temperature from normal to slight or moderate fever zone (up to 38.3uC) were observed among meditators only during the Forceful Breath type of g-tummo meditation accompanied by increases in alpha, beta, and gamma power. Without meditative visualization, both meditators and non-meditators were capable of using the Forceful Breath vase breathing only for a limited time, resulting in limited temperature increases in the range of normal body temperature.

data.Author: Kramer
data.Title: The Effectiveness of A Slow-Paced Diaphragmatic Breathing Exercise in Children's Daily Life: A Micro-Randomized Trial
data.Journal: JOURNAL OF CLINICAL CHILD AND ADOLESCENT PSYCHOLOGY
data.Control: Watching a different video (active control condition) or passive control condition
data.Overall effect:
The breathing exercise had no immediate effects on negative affect or relaxation compared
to both control conditions. However, in situations when children reported higher levels of
worries than usual, relaxation was higher when children performed the breathing exercise compared
to the passive control condition. Compared to the active control condition, the breathing
exercise did not result in higher levels of relaxation in situations when children worried more than
normally.

data.Author: Krasnikov
data.Title: Analysis of heart rate variability and skin blood flow oscillations under deep controlled breathing
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min × 7 times (1 spontaneous breathing, 6 different paced deep breathing)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart rate variability (HRV) and respiration-dependent oscillations of forearm/finger skin blood flow (SBF)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect: A bell-shaped dependence of the respiration-related component of HRV spectrum on breathing rate, with the maximum at 0.05–0.07 Hz. On the contrary, the amplitude of respiration-related oscillations of SBFfinger and SBFforearm has been shown to be independent of breathing rate.

data.Author: Kromenacker
data.Title: Vagal Mediation of Low-Frequency Heart Rate Variability During Slow Yogic Breathing
data.Overall effect: HRV power across the low-frequency range (4–9 breaths/minute) was nearly eliminated (p = .016) by parasympathetic blockade compared with placebo. In contrast, spectral power during sympathetic blockade and placebo was statistically indistinguishable.

data.Author: Kumar
data.Title: Immediate effect of slow right and left nostril deep breathing exercises on reaction time, pain sensitivity, and temperature of elderly population in Madurai
data.Journal: National Journal of Physiology, Pharmacy and Pharmacology
data.Population category (students, general,:
Elderly people in the Private Medical College campus who were either 
working in the hospital or acquaintances of the patients
data.Type of breathing practice: Right or left nostril breathing (6 breaths/min)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Visual reaction time (VRT), auditory reaction time (ART), pain sensitivity, and temperature
data.Overall effect: Right nostril breathing decreases reaction time and increases pain sensitivity without affecting body temperature. Left nostril breathing increases reaction time but decreases pain sensitivity, and body temperature.

data.Author: Kunal
data.Title: Impact of regularly supervised training of pranayama and omkar meditation on the cardio-respiratory parameters and short-term memory of persons with special needs
data.Type of breathing practice: Nadishodhana pranayama apalabhati and Aum Chanting
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Basic cardio-respiratory parameters (respiratory rate, pulse, systolic and diastolic blood pressures) and short-term-memory
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function, Cognition
data.Overall effect: The pranayama and meditation has beneficial influences on heart rate, breathing rate and short-term-memory of mentally-challenged people.

data.Author: Kuula
data.Title: The Effects of Presleep Slow Breathing and Music Listening on Polysomnographic Sleep Measures - a pilot trial
data.Population: Individuals with a relatively stable sleep schedule
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Sleep quality, heart rate, and EEG power spectral density
data.Primary Outcome Category: Sleep related/fatigue, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect: While some indices pointed to improved sleep quality in both groups (breathing or music listening groups), neither condition had robust effects on sleep quality.

data.Author: Laborde
data.Title: Psychophysiological effects of slow-paced breathing at six cycles per minute with or without heart rate variability biofeedback
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Emotional and perceived stress intensity, and the root mean square of the successive differences (RMSSD) as a
physiologic variable
data.Primary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: For pre and post comparisons (referring, respectively, to before and after slow-paced breathing (SPB)), both SPB-HRVB (HRV Biofeedback) and SPB-NoHRVB (No HRV Biofeedback) conditions resulted in a more negative emotional valence, lower emotional arousal, higher emotional control, and higher the root mean square of the successive differences (RMSSD).

data.Author: Laborde
data.Title: Influence of a 30-Day Slow-Paced Breathing Intervention Compared to Social Media Use on Subjective Sleep Quality and Cardiac Vagal Activity
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Sleep quality and cardiac vagal activity
data.Primary Outcome Category: Sleep related/fatigue, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: Compared to the use of social media, the slow-paced breathing technique improved subjective sleep quality and increased overnight cardiac vagal activity, while a tendency was observed for morning awakening

data.Author: Laborde
data.Title: Influence of Slow-Paced Breathing on Inhibition After Physical Exertion
data.Population category (students, general,:
Students at the German 
Sport University.
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Cardiac vagal activity and perceived stress
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect: Slow-paced breathing realized before or after physical exertion has a positive effect regarding adaptation to psychological stress and specifically inhibition.

data.Author: Larsen
data.Title: Effect of Deep Slow Breathing on Pain-Related Variables in Osteoarthritis
data.Condition:
Osteoarthritis of 
their hip or knee
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Pain, physical function, and heart rate variability
data.Primary Outcome Category: Pain Perception, Muscular Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: The six-week deep slow breathing program was not sufficient to alleviate pain or improve physical function in subjects with lower extremity joint pain.

data.Author: Larson
data.Title: Slow-Paced Breathing and Autonomic Function in People Post-stroke
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Baroreflex sensitivity (BRS), heart rate variability (HRV), and lower blood pressure (BP)
data.Overall effect: In people post-stroke, slow breathing may increase Baroreflex sensitivity (BRS), particularly elevations in blood pressure, more than a typical breathing space.

data.Author: Lee
data.Title: Effects of deep and slow breathing on stress stimulation caused by high-intensity exercise in healthy adults
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Chain-reaction changes of stress stimulation and heart rate variability (HRV)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect:
Deep and slow breathing group(DSBG) had higher values of alpha/high-beta ratio and High-Frequency (HF) value of HRV than control group (p <.05), and Low-
Frequency/High-Frequency (LF/HF) ratio of DSBG is significant time group interaction, indicating a significant difference between groups (p <.05).

data.Author: Lehrer
data.Title: Zazen and cardiac variability
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Increased oscillation amplitude during slow breathing is caused by resonance between cardiac variability caused by respiration and that produced by physiological processes underlying slower rhythms.

data.Author: Levin
data.Title: The impact of deep breathing and alternate nostril breathing on heart rate variability: a human physiology laboratory
data.Population category (students, general,:
Undergraduates enrolled in a physiology
course designed for nonscience majors
data.Type of breathing practice: Deep breathing (DB) or alternate nostril breathing (ARB)
data.Breathing Category: Slow Deep Breathing, Alternate Nostril Breathing
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 3 min × 2 times (1 time deep breathing and 1 time alternate nostril breathing)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart rate variability and the SD of instantaneous heart rate (SDHR)
data.Overall effect: Heart rate was significantly, albeit slightly, elevated from normal during deep breathing(DB), but not during alternate nostril breathing (ANB), Analysis of the SD of instantaneous heart rate showed significant differences between conditions,

data.Author: Li
data.Title: Effects of slow breathing rate on heart rate variability and arterial baroreflex sensitivity in essential hypertension
data.Condition: Patients withssential hypertension and healthy individuals
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min × 2 times (1 time 8 breaths/min and 1 time 16 breaths/min)
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Heart rate, blood pressure and respiratory peak, high-frequency (HF) power, low-frequency (LF) power, and LF/
HF ratio of heart rate variability
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Slow breathing can increase high-frequency(HF) power and decrease low-frequency(LF) power and LF/HF ratio in essential hypertension. Besides, slow breathing increased baroreflex sensitivity in hypertensive subjects.

data.Author: Liboriussen
data.Title: Investigating the Dose-Response Relationship between Deep Breathing and Heart Rate Variability in Healthy Participants and Across-Days Reliability in Patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis and Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
data.Pop Characteristic: General Population / Specialized Groups and Practitioners
data.Duration of breathing exercise: (1)healthy; 5, 10, and 15 min in a randomized order on 3 different days (2)Patients; 30 min on two different days
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing (DB) increases heart rate variability in healthy participants and Rheumatoid Arthritis or Systemic Lupus Erythematosus patients, which indicates stimulation of the vagus nerve. Of the tested durations, 30 min of DB was the optimal period of stimulation.

data.Author: Limberg
data.Title: Respiratory influences on muscle sympathetic nerve activity and vascular conductance in the steady state
data.Journal: Am J Physiol Heart Circ Physiol
data.Condition: Free from overt cardiovascular disease and neurological disorders
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Muscle sympathetic nerve activity, forearm blood flow, forearm vascular conductance, and blood pressure
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Muscular Function
data.Overall effect: The alterations in breathing frequency (7, 14, and 21 breaths/min) and volume did not affect steady-state levels of sympathetic activity, blood flow, vascular conductance, or blood pressure (all P ＞ 0.05), even though they had the expected effect on sympathetic activity within breaths (i.e., increased modulation during low-frequency/high-tidal volume breathing) (P ＜ 0.001).

data.Author: Lucas
data.Title: Slow breathing as a means to improve orthostatic tolerance: a randomized sham-controlled trial
data.Overall effect: Tolerance time to presyncope was improved (＋15%) with slow breathing compared with spontaneous breathing.

data.Author: Peterson

The study recommends considering yogic breathing as an integrative approach for the management of patients with COVID

Breathing frequency did not differentially impact accuracy or variability across conditions.
