data.Overall effect: During slow deep breathing, cardio-respiratory coupling, mean arterial pressure decreased, and heart rate variability varied. Repeated practice may strengthen cardiorespiratory coupling.

data.Author: Ghiya
data.Title: Cardiac Autonomic Control During Alternate Nostril Breathing at a Slow Breathing Rate
data.Journal: MEDICINE AND SCIENCE IN SPORTS AND EXERCISE
data.Type of breathing practice: Alternate nostril breathing, slow paced breathing
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: heart rate variability and blood pressure
data.Overall effect: Alternate nose breathing had higher heart rate than the other conditions. Parasympathetic acticity decreased or sympathetic acticity in the heart increased during each breahting consition. Alternate nose breathing may create less of a reduction in parasympathetic control.

data.Author: Malhotra
data.Title: Immediate autonomic changes during right nostril breathing and left nostril breathing in regular yoga practitioners
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 min × 2 times (right nosil breathing × 1, left nosil breathing × 1)
data.Overall effect: Changes in HRV were seen after 5 min of right nostril breathing and left nostril breathing. However, statistically, there is not much difference in the immediate effects of the two pranayamas on heart rate variability in regular yoga practitioners.

data.Author: Manandhar
data.Title: Immediate Effect of Slow Deep Breathing Exercise on Blood Pressure and Reaction Time
data.Overall effect: A significant decrease in reaction time was noted among the whole study population, though decreases in systolic and diastolic pressure were recorded unstatistical significantly in all.

data.Author: Martarelli
data.Title: Diaphragmatic breathing reduces exercise-induced oxidative stress
data.Control: Sat in an equivalent quite place
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Oxidative stress, cortisol and melatonin hormones
data.Overall effect: Relaxation induced by diaphragmatic breathing increased the antioxidant defense status in athletes after exhaustive exercise. These effects correlate with the concomitant decrease in cortisol and the increase in melatonin.

data.Author: Martin
data.Title: Respiration-induced hypoalgesia: exploration of potential mechanisms
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 6 min × 6 times (2 slow, 2 normal, and 2 fast)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Respiration rate, heart rate variability (HRV), heart rate, and subjective arousal
data.Primary Outcome Category: Respiratory Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: Slow breathing reduced pain relative to normal breathing and fast breathing, but nociceptive flexion reflex (NFR) was not influenced by breathing.

data.Author: Mason
data.Title: Cardiovascular and respiratory effect of yogic slow breathing in the yoga beginner: what is the best approach?
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 3 min (Spontaneous breathing) + 2 min × 6 times (1 fats, and 5 slow with different patterns of inspiration and expiration and with or without ujjayi)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: The slow breathing with equal inspiration and expiration seems the best technique for improving baroreflex ensitivity in yoga-naive subjects. The effects of ujjayi seems dependent on increased intrathoracic pressure that requires greater effort than normal slow breathing.

data.Author: Matic
data.Title: Slow 0.1 Hz Breathing and Body Posture Induced Perturbations of RRI and Respiratory Signal Complexity and Cardiorespiratory Coupling
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 15 min (1 supine and 1 standing at spontaneous breathing, 1 supine and 1 standing at slow-paced breathing)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Electrocardiac RR interval, respiratory signal Detrended Fluctuation, Multiple Scaling Entropy(MSE), and cross MSE
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Specific and comprehensive cardiorespiratory regulation in standing with slow breathing suggests this state as the potentially most beneficial maneuver for cardiorespiratory conditioning.

data.Author: Mawar
data.Title: Sudarshan Kriya yoga improves quality of life in healthy people living with HIV (PLHIV): results from an open label randomized clinical trial
data.Condition: HIV, above with CD4 count above 400 cell/µl and Karnofsky scale26 score above 70
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Physical Measurements and Anthropometric Parameters
data.Overall effect: A significant improvement in QOL scores was observed for the three health related QOL domains in SKY intervention arm.

data.Author: McClain
data.Title: An Acute Bout of a Controlled Breathing Frequency Lowers Sympathetic Neural Outflow but not Blood Pressure in Healthy Normotensive Subjects
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 6 min × 2 times (1 spontaneous breathing, 1 controlled breathing)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart rate, Blood pressure (systolic, SBP; diastolic, DBP), and muscle sympathetic nerve activity
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Neurological Function
data.Overall effect: Muscle sympathetic nerve activity (MSNA) burst frequency and MSNA burst incidence were significantly lower than during spontaneous breathing. Heart rate was higher during controlled breathing. SBP, DBP, and MSNA total activity were not different between the breathing conditions.

data.Author: Aacharya
data.Title: Cerebral Hemodynamics and Vagally Mediated HRV Associated with High- and Low-frequency Yoga Breathing: an Exploratory, Randomized, Crossover Study
data.Type of breathing practice:
Bumblebee Yoga Breathing (BBYB / Bhramari Pranayama)

High-Frequency Yoga Breathing (HFYB / Kapalabhati)
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Cerebral blood flow (MCA velocity, PI)
Vagal modulation (VmHRV)
data.Primary Outcome Category: Neurological Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Secondary Outcome of interest:
Respiratory waveform and rate
Hyperventilation symptoms (via Nijmegen questionnaire)
data.Overall effect:
In summary during both HFYB and BBYB, the TCD 
recordings showed decreased MCA flow velocities and 
increased resistance to cerebral blood flow

data.Author: Alford
data.Title:
A quality improvement study on the feasibility and potential benefits of a
yogic breathing program for cancer survivors and caregivers during
treatment in a lodging facility
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Improvements in mood, pain, appetite, relaxation, sleep, breathing
data.Secondary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Pain Perception, Sleep related/fatigue, Respiratory Function, Physiological Symptoms
data.Overall effect:
Yogic breathing could be 
effective in reducing some of the side effects of cancer treatment, which 
could be used to improve the quality of life of cancer patients and 
caregivers.

data.Author: Bakyaraj
data.Title:
Physiological Basis of Deep Breathing Exercises in Chronic Pain
Management
data.Journal:
Research Journal of Pharmaceutical, Biological and Chemical
Sciences
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Reduction in specific symptoms (e.g., headache, joint pain, muscle pain)
data.Overall effect: approximately 70% of patients practicing deep breathing experienced significant pain relief

data.Author: Bana´s-Ząbczyk
data.Title:
Breathing-based meditation (Sudarshan Kriya Yoga) increases sense of
coherence. No-cost stress prevention
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Components of SOC – comprehensibility, manageability, meaningfulness
data.Overall effect: The practice of Sudarshan Kriya Yoga) can increase the sense of coherence after 6-day of practice by 12%

data.Author: Bhasker
data.Title: Effects of Sudarshan KriyaYoga and Advanced Meditation Program on Genetic Expression of Pro-inflammatory and Antioxidants Genes.
data.Condition: Healthy, however, come from historically stressed/disadvantaged social group
data.Age: Group I: 38.8 ± 11.9 years; Group II: 36.4 ± 9.3 years
data.Type of breathing practice: Sudarshan Kriya Yoga (SKY) and Advanced Meditation Program
data.Duration of breathing exercise: Daily SKY (30 minutes/day); AMP lasted 4 days with multiple meditation sessions
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Expression of pro-inflammatory genes (IL1β, IL6, TNF)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Expression of antioxidant genes (SOD, catalase, GPx)
data.Overall effect:
In summary, the study suggests that the regular practice of SKY helps us in dealing with stressors in a better way; moreover, the
incorporation of hollow and empty meditation improves the responses, making the person resilient.

data.Author: Buxton
data.Title: The Effects of Slow Breathing during Inter-Set Recovery on Power Performance in the Barbell Back Squat
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 2 minutes of 4-7-8 breathing during 3-min rest (after 1-min spontaneous breathing)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Power and bar velocity during back squat
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Heart rate recovery, systolic blood pressure, perceived exertion, perceived recovery
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Physical Fitness
data.Overall effect: there was a improved heart rate recovery but there wasn't a sognificant impact

data.Author: Chand
data.Title:
A comprehensive evaluation of linear and non-linear HRV
parameters between paced breathing and stressful mental state
data.Duration of intervention/study: Single session with two 5-minute interventions, separated by 15-minute washout
data.Type of breathing practice: Paced breathing at 6 breaths per minute
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Change in linear and non-linear HRV parameters
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Correlation patterns among HRV parameters under stress vs relaxation
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect: Overall, HRV parameters can be reliably used to assess a person’s relaxed and stressed mental states during paced breathing and mental arithmetic task respectively.

data.Author: Chhajer
data.Title: Examining the impact of a restorative breath-based intervention "Sudarshan Kriya Yoga" at work: a field experiment
data.Type of breathing practice: Sudarshan Kriya Yoga (SKY), including Ujjayi, Bhastrika, Om chanting, and rhythmic SKY breath
data.Breathing Category: Sudarshan Kriya Yoga (SKY), Ujjayi Breathing, Bhastrika (Bellows Breath)
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 6 hours/day; specific breathwork sessions varied within the structure
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Thriving at work, emotional, social, psychological well-being, and general health
data.Overall effect: The findings provide support for considering SKY as a potential wellbeing intervention for employers at the workplace and society at large

data.Author: Chick
data.Title: A school-based health and mindfulness curriculum improves children's objectively measured sleep: a prospective observational cohort study
data.Duration of breathing exercise: Twice a week for two years, each session 15–50 minutes
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Total sleep time (TST) and REM sleep duration imporved
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Social stress (BASC Social Problems subscale), engagement with curriculum
data.Overall effect: Children receiving the curriculum gained an average of 74 minutes of total sleep time, and 24 minutes of rapid eye movement sleep while children not receiving the curriculum experienced a decrease in total sleep time averaging 64 minutes per night, with no changes in rapid eye movement sleep.

data.Author: Dada
data.Title:
Effect of “365 Breathing Technique” on Intraocular Pressure
and Autonomic Functions in Patients With Glaucoma:
A Randomized Controlled Trial
data.Type of breathing practice: "365 breathing" – slow nasal breathing at 6 breaths/min for 5 minutes, 3 times a day
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 minutes per session, 3 times per day for 6 weeks
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Serum cortisol, heart rate variability, blood pressure, delta HR, E:I ratio
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Biochemical and Metabolic Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: There was a significant reduction in IOP, serum cortisol, and improved parasympathetic activity

data.Author: Finan
data.Title:
Effects of Savoring Meditation on Positive Emotions and Pain-Related Brain Function: A
Mechanistic Randomized Controlled Trial in People With Rheumatoid Arthritis
data.Duration of intervention/study: 2 weeks for intervention + immediate post-intervention assessments
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 4 sessions × 20 minutes = 80 minutes total over 2 weeks
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Neural activity during pain (fMRI: vmPFC, NAc) and pain sensitivity
data.Overall effect: Overall findings show that Savoring Meditation is acutely analgesic, modulates CBF within corticostriatal circuitry during noxious stimulation, and leads to increases in positive emotions and decreases in anhedonic symptoms without altering negative emotions.

data.Author: Gündogdu
data.Title: The Effects of Pranayama or Deep Breathing Exercises on Fatigue and Sleep Quality in Women Receiving Radiation Therapy for Breast Cancer
data.Population: 60 women with stage II–III breast cancer undergoing radiation therapy
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Sleep quality (measured by Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index)
data.Overall effect:
For pranayama, ethere was improved sleep quality and fatigue remained stable
For deep breathing there was no significant change in fatigue or sleep
For control the fatigue and sleep worsened

data.Author: Harris
data.Title: Mindful Attention to Breath With or Without Yogic Breathing Decreases Smoking Choice: A Preliminary Laboratory Investigation
data.Study design: Controlled laboratory-based experimental study with random assignment
data.Duration of intervention/study: Single session; 20-minute intervention, followed by 50-minute observation task
data.Type of breathing practice:
MAB (Mindful Attention to Breath)
MYB (Mindful Yogic Breathing / Ujjayi pranayama)
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 20 minutes (5 min guided instruction + 15 min practice)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Smoking choice (whether participant smoked during the 50-min task)
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Anxiety/depression, Physiological Symptoms, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect: Findings suggest MAB is an easily disseminable and cost-effective strategy that may promote smoking abstinence and should be further explored

data.Author: Hu
data.Title: Effect of Short-term Deep Breathing Exercises on Perioperative Anxiety and Pain in Pediatric Orthopedic Patients: a Randomized Controlled Trial
data.Condition: Pediatric patients about to undergo orthopedic surgery
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Perioperative anxiety and pain in pediatric patients and their parents
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Parental anxiety and child's postoperative anxiety/pain correlations were examined
data.Overall effect: Short-term deep breathing exercises were ineffective in reducing perioperative pain and anxiety in pediatric orthopedic patients

data.Author: Kamath
data.Title: Impact of yoga on the cognitive function among desk‐based workers
data.Population: Physically inactive young adults from a university
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 3 minutes every hour (total of 12 minutes over 4 hours)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Reaction time (measured via Flanker and N-back tests)
data.Overall effect: There was significant improvements in reaction time for pranayama group compared to sitting; less clear for accuracy

data.Author: Kanchibhotla
data.Title: Influence of yogic breathing in increasing social connectedness among Indian adults
data.Study design: Open trial, pre-post intervention design (no control group)
data.Population:
473 participants for pre-post assessment
112 participants completed follow-up (day 40)
data.Duration of breathing exercise: Each session = 30 minutes, daily practice encouraged for 40 days
data.Overall effect:
The study suggested a positive connection between the SKY practice and subsequent improvement in social connectedness. The reduction in stress levels post SKY program as indicated in the study may be a reason of 
enhanced social connectedness

data.Author: Kobayashi
data.Title: Acute effects of the 4-4-8 breathing technique on arterial stiffness in healthy young men
data.Duration of intervention/study: Single session with measurements at baseline, 30 min, 60 min, and 24 h post-intervention
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Blood pressure (brachial SBP), heart rate variability (HF, LF)
data.Overall effect: There was a significant acute decrease in baPWV, SBP, LF and an increase in HF

data.Author: Korkmaz
data.Title:
Sudarshan Kriya Yoga Breathing and a Meditation Program for Burnout 
Among Physicians
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Depression, Anxiety, and Stress Scale (DASS-42); and insomnia measured by the Regensburg 
Insomnia Scale (RIS) with primary end point at postintervention (8 weeks)
data.Overall effect: In this randomized clinical trial of physicians, participants in the SKY group displayed significantly reduced rates of depression, anxiety, and stress compared with control participants.

data.Author: Kushwaha
data.Title: Effect of Pranayama and Meditation on Emotional Intelligence among Undergraduate Students: A Randomized Controlled Study
data.Journal: International Journal of Ayurvedic Medicine (Peer-reviewed journal)
data.Breathing Category: Nadi Shodhan Pranayama, Bhastrika (Bellows Breath), Bhramari (Bee-Humming Breath)
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 60 min/day (30 min pranayama + 25 min vipassana + prayer), 6 days/week, for 10 weeks
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Emotional Intelligence (assessed by Emotional Intelligence Scale - EIS)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Anxiety, Depression, and Stress (assessed by ADSS scale
data.Overall effect:
The study suggests that pranayama and mindfulness 
(vipassana) meditation can be useful to enhance EI and reduce anxiety, depression, and stress in UG students.

data.Author: Liang
data.Title: Acute effect of breathing exercises on muscle tension and executive function under psychological stress
data.Study design: Within-subject design, randomized sequence of interventions
data.Primary Outcome of interest:
Muscle tension (via surface EMG)
Executive function (via Stroop Test accuracy and reaction time)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest:
Respiration rate (RR), Oxygen saturation (SpO2),
End-tidal CO₂ (EtCO₂), Preferred breathing method
data.Overall effect: Results show that brief breathing exercises did not substantially aect muscle tension under psychological stres

data.Author: Harshwardhan
data.Title: To Investigate the Impact of a Brief Period of Pranayama Practice on the Cardiovascular Autonomic Function in Patients Diagnosed with Hypothyroidism
data.Journal: International Journal of Current Pharmaceutical Review and Research
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 28 minutes per session (5 min loosening + 2 min each of 4 pranayama types + 15 min shavasana), 3 times/week supervised
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Cardiovascular autonomic function improvements (via deep breathing test, valsalva ratio, handgrip and cold pressor test)
data.Overall effect: The results of this study demonstrated that regular practice of pranayama in addition to standard medical therapy is more beneficial to improve cardiovascular autonomic function in hypothyroid patients.

data.Author: Jyskä
data.Title: Effects of Using Guided Deep Breathing Exercises in a Virtual Natural Environment to Reduce Stress during Pediatric Treatment.
data.Type of breathing practice: Guided deep breathing with animation and avatar in VR
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Stress reduction (measured via HRV: SDNN, RMSSD, Stress Index, LF/HF ratio)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Pain/anxiety scores via adapted VAS-A questionnaire
data.Overall effect: There was statistically significant reductions in physiological stress (HRV data); subjective feedback largely positive

data.Author: Kavitha
data.Title: Effects of Slow Breathing Exercises on Cardiac Autonomic Functions in Anxiety Disorder—A Randomised Control Trial
data.Journal: Peer-reviewed journal (Annals of Neurosciences, Original Article)

data.Breathing Category: Nadi Shodhan Pranayama, Bhramari (Bee-Humming Breath), Sheetali and Sheetkari Pranayamas
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Blood pressure (SBP, DBP), heart rate (HR), MAP, RPP, autonomic reactivity tests
data.Overall effect: There was significant improvements in HRV, BRS, parasympathetic activity; decrease in sympathetic activity and BP

data.Author: Li, X
data.Title: Neural correlates of breath work, mental imagery of yoga postures, and meditation in yoga practitioners: a functional near-infrared spectroscopy study
data.Study design: Comparative cross-sectional experimental study using functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS)
data.Age: Long-term: Mean 31.95 yrs; Short-term: Mean 28.50 yrs
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Oxygenated hemoglobin (HbO) changes in PFC regions during tasks
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Self-rated mastery of postures; regional efficiency of neural activation
data.Overall effect:
Breath work: ↑ DLPFC activity (better cognitive control)

Mental imagery: ↓ VLPFC activity in long-term practitioners (more efficiency)

Meditation: ↑ OFC & VLPFC activation (better emotional & self-regulatory control)

data.Author: Li, Z
data.Title: Unraveling the Temporal Interplay of Slow-Paced Breathing and Prefrontal Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation on Cardiac Indices of Autonomic Activity
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Physical (heart rate variability, heart rate, blood pressure, skin conductance)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Heart rate, blood pressure, skin conductance level
data.Overall effect: SPB increased vmHRV and decreased HR; tDCS alone increased HR; no combined synergistic effect

data.Author: Mahalakshmi
data.Title: Deep breathing exercises in easing educational stress among Indian high school students
data.Population: Higher secondary (high school) students in Visnagar, India
data.Duration of breathing exercise: It is daily but not exactly stated

data.Author: Mahmood

data.Secondary Outcome of interest: EEG brain wave activity (beta, delta, theta, alpha, gamma)

data.Author: Mazur

data.Author: Niu

alleviate premature ejaculation (PE) symptoms

data.Author: Rafiq

data.Type of breathing practice: Slow deep breathing (5 sec inhale + 5 sec exhale)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Change in heart rate and blood pressure
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, heart rate variability (HRV)
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Respiratory Function, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect: It significantly reduced heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate; increased HRV and oxygen saturation

data.Author: Ramalingam
data.Title: Effect of six-week short-duration deep breathing on young adults with chronic ankle instability—a pilot randomized control trial
data.Journal:
BMC Sports Science, 
Medicine and Rehabilitation
data.Population: 30 young adult males with chronic ankle instability (CAI)
data.Overall effect: Improvement in pain, balance, mindfulness, and happiness, especially in experimental group

data.Author: Rezaei
data.Title: Effect of deep diaphragmatic breathing on pain in patients with metastatic gastrointestinal cancers
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Chronic pain (VanKorff Questionnaire – intensity, disability, duration)
data.Overall effect: There was significant reduction in both acute and chronic pain

data.Author: Robertson
data.Title: Investigating a deep breathing intervention to promote mental health in P‐12 schools
data.Study design: Qualitative study using Consensual Qualitative Research (CQR)
data.Population: School staff and students in P–12 schools
data.Condition: Mental health challenges including trauma, anxiety, stress, emotional dysregulation
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Emotional regulation (de-escalation, calming, readiness to learn)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Focus, classroom behavior, application outside school
data.Overall effect: It overall improved emotional regulation, student-led breathing, greater focus, and carryover outside school

data.Author: Saraswati
data.Title: The Impact of Yoga on Athletes' Mental Well-Being: An Experimental Study
data.Study design: Pre- and post-test randomized experimental design
data.Population: 44 recreational athletes from Banaras Hindu University
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Anxiety/depression, General well-being/quality of life, Sleep related/fatigue
data.Overall effect: Positive significant improvement in all outcomes

data.Author: Shahid
data.Title: Effects of Deep Breathing Exercises on Old Versus Young Patients Undergoing Valve Replacement Surgery
data.Duration of intervention/study: 5 months total study period; 2 weeks intervention per patient
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5–10 minutes per session, 3 sessions/week for 2 weeks
data.Overall effect: Significant improvement in oxygen saturation, especially in young patients

data.Author: Singh, H
data.Title:
Immediate effect of short duration of slow deep breathing on heart rate 
and blood pressure in healthy young adults
data.Overall effect: Significant immediate reduction in heart rate and blood pressure

data.Author: Sree
data.Title: Effect of Simha Kriya on Expiratory Flow Rates in Healthy Adults
data.Journal: International Journal of Academic Medicine and Pharmacy
data.Population category (students, general,: General volunteers at a yoga center
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 10 minutes per session, twice daily, 6 days/week, for 6 months
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Forced Vital Capacity (FVC), Forced Expiratory Flow
data.Overall effect: Significant improvement in all measured pulmonary function parameters

data.Author: Stick
data.Title: Deep abdominal breathing reduces heart rate and symptoms during orthostatic challenge in patients with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart rate (mean and max) during standing
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Physiological Symptoms
data.Overall effect: Significant improvement in both HR and symptom scores

data.Author: Sun
data.Title:
Effects of 7-minute practices of breathing and meditation on stress 
reduction
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Affective outcomes (serenity, anxiety, fatigue, active emotion)
data.Secondary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Anxiety/depression, Sleep related/fatigue
data.Overall effect: Significant reduction in perceived stress, anxiety, and fatigue; increase in serenity and active emotion

data.Author: Tian
data.Title: Combined effect of transcutaneous auricular vagus nerve stimulation and 0.1 Hz slow-paced breathing on working memory
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 30 minutes for each intervention. A 10-minute training session for SPB was conducted before the formal sessions.
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Accuracy in matching trials (mACC), mismatching trials (mismACC), and reaction time in accurate trials (aRT) on the spatial and digit n-back tasks.
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: The study used spatial and digit n-back tasks (1-back and 3-back) to assess working memory.
data.Overall effect: Both taVNS and combined taVNS + SPB improved working memory performance (specifically, accuracy in the spatial 3-back task). SPB alone did not show a significant improvement in working memory performance

data.Author: Tisdell
data.Title:
The Efects of Heart Rhythm Meditation on Vagal Tone 
and Well‑being: A Mixed Methods Research Study
data.Duration of intervention/study: A six-week course to learn Heart Rhythm Meditation (HRM) , followed by engaging in daily practice for 10 weeks
data.Type of breathing practice: Heart Rhythm Meditation (HRM), which involves a deep, slow, full rhythmic breath, synchronizing breath with heartbeat.
data.Primary Outcome of interest: vagal activity (measured by HRV) and participants' well-being.
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, General well-being/quality of life
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: positive effects of HRM on stress and well-being, the development of a more expanded sense of self, and an increased awareness of the interconnection of the body-heart-emotions and HRM's role in emotion regulation.
data.Overall effect: The HRM practice has a positive effects on stress and well-being.

data.Author: Unudurthi
data.Title:
Sudarshan Kriya Meditation Reduces
Substance Abuse Cravings and Improves
Physical and Emotional Well-Being of
Individuals With Opioid Use Disorder
data.Study design: Mixed methods study with a quasi-experimental (pre-post) design and qualitative analysis of participant journals.
data.Duration of intervention/study: initial 5-day program (3 hours/day), followed by weekly follow-up sessions and daily home practice for 1 month
data.Condition: High levels of comorbidity between OUD and mental illnesses such as depression, anxiety, and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Significant decrease in substance use cravings and depression.
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Significant increase in physical functioning and emotional well-being.
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Physical Fitness, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect: The SKY intervention led to a significant decrease in substance use cravings and depression at 1-month post-intervention.

data.Author: Verma
data.Title: The Positive Effect of Deep Breathing Exercises on Blood Pressure Values among Hypertensive Persons
data.Journal: Journal of Indian College of Cardiology
data.Study design: Quantitative research approach, quasi-experimental research design
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Blood pressure values (systolic and diastolic blood pressure)
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing exercises were concluded to be effective in reducing both systolic and diastolic blood pressure values among hypertensive persons in the experimental group.

data.Author: Yendodu
data.Title: Effect of Deep Breathing Exercise using Smartwatch on Behaviour, Anxiety and Pain in Children during Buccal Infiltration Anaesthesia-A Randomised Clinical Trial
data.Journal: Journal of Clinical and Diagnostic Research.
data.Study design: A prospective interventional and single-blinded randomised clinical trial
data.Duration of intervention/study: The study was conducted from November 2019 to October 2020.
data.Condition: Children undergoing maxillary buccal infiltration anaesthesia for dental procedures and their anxiety
data.Duration of breathing exercise: The deep breathing exercise was performed during the maxillary buccal infiltration anaesthesia procedure.
data.Primary Outcome of interest: effect of deep breathing exercise in reducing dental anxiety, improving behavior, and reducing pain in children during maxillary buccal infiltration
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Frankl's behaviour rating scale, anxiety using the Facial Image Scale, Modified Corah Dental Anxiety Scale, pulse rate, oxygen saturation, and respiratory rate, and pain using the Face Pain Scale-Revised.
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Anxiety/depression, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function, Pain Perception
data.Overall effect: Deep breathing exercise using a smartwatch significantly reduced dental anxiety, improved behavior, and reduced pain in children during maxillary buccal infiltration anesthesia comapred to control group

data.Author: You
data.Title: Influence of Respiratory Frequency of Slow-Paced Breathing on Vagally-Mediated Heart Rate Variability
data.Primary Outcome of interest: effects of brief SPB interventions on Cardiac Vagal Activity (CVA) using Heart Rate Variability (HRV) measurement as an index.
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: CVA can help manage stress and regulate emotions
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Anxiety/depression, General well-being/quality of life
data.Overall effect:
The results of the present study show that any SPB respiratory frequency between 5 cpm and 7 cpm would trigger an 
increase in CVA, in comparison to a spontaneous respiratory 
frequency, in line with the findings of a recent meta-analysis

data.Author: Yuenyongchaiwat
data.Title: Effects of slow breathing training on hemodynamic changes, cardiac autonomic function and neuroendocrine response in people with high blood pressure: a randomized control trial
data.Population category (students, general,: Participants were individuals diagnosed with high blood pressure.
data.Duration of breathing exercise:
30 min per day, for 5 days per _x000D_
week
data.Primary Outcome of interest: effects of slow breathing training on hemodynamic changes (blood pressure, heart rate), cardiac autonomic function (heart rate variability), and neuroendocrine response (salivary cortisol) in people with high blood pressure.
data.Primary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Biochemical and Metabolic Function
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: study measures systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, mean arterial pressure, heart rate, heart rate variability parameters (RMSSD, SDNN, LF, HF, LF/HF ratio), and salivary cortisol levels.
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Biochemical and Metabolic Function
data.Overall effect: This study provided evidence demonstrating the effect of SBT on cardiac autonomic and stress reactivity, which has important implications for health promotion in people with high BP.

data.Author: Apurwa
data.Title:
IMPACT OF BREATHING EXERCISE AND MEDITATION ON HEART RATE VARIABILITY AMONG
PERIMENOPAUSAL WOMEN: A PROSPECTIVE COHORT STUDY
data.Journal: International Journal of Medicine and Public Health
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Heart Rate Variability (HRV), specifically HF%, LF/HF ratio
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Average heart rate, SD1, SD2, SDRR, RMSSD
data.Overall effect:
Three months of daily breathing exercise and meditation 
improves the HRV in perimenopausal women.

data.Author: Bhardwaj
data.Title: Efficacy of mHealth aided 12-week meditation and breath intervention on change in burnout and professional quality of life among health care providers of a tertiary care hospital in north India: a randomized waitlist-controlled trial
data.Condition: Occupational burnout and reduced professional quality of life
data.Population category (students, general,: Healthcare providers (HCPs): resident doctors, medical students, nursing officers, staff
data.Type of breathing practice: Sudarshan Kriya: Ujjayi, Bhastrika, Om chanting, rhythmic breathing
data.Breathing Category: Sudarshan Kriya Yoga (SKY), Ujjayi Breathing, Bhastrika (Bellows Breath)
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Maslach Burnout Inventory: emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, personal accomplishment
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Professional Quality of Life (PQL): compassion satisfaction, burnout, secondary trauma; Heart rate, BP
data.Secondary Outcome Category: General well-being/quality of life, Anxiety/depression, Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements
data.Overall effect:
The current study contributes to the existing evidence on the 
effectiveness of Yoga in managing stress and developing resilience among doctors, nurses, and other medical professionals. Integrating yoga into healthcare settings is crucial for addressing the detrimental impact of burnout on decisionmaking and promoting positive patient outcomes.

data.Author: Birdee
data.Title: Slow breathing for reducing stress: The effect of extending exhale
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 45 minutes per class, weekly private classes for 12 weeks
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Physiological stress measured by spectral analyses of heart rate variability (HF HRV) and psychological stress measured by PROMIS Anxiety
data.Overall effect: While slow breathing significantly reduces psychological stress, breath ratios do not have a significant differential effect on stress reduction among healthy adults.

data.Author: Catela
data.Title: Heart Rate Variability, Blood Pressure and Peripheral Oxygen Saturation during Yoga Adham and Mahat Breathing Techniques without Retention in Adult Practitioners
data.Journal: Journal of Functional Morphology and Kinesiology
data.Duration of intervention/study: Single-session, acute intervention (10 minutes per breathing condition)
data.Condition: general population with some having conditions like hypertension, asthma, heart problems, psychiatric support
data.Pop Condition: Healthy Individuals, Hypertensive Patients, Cardiovascular Diseases, Respiratory Conditions, Mental Health Disorders
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Blood pressure and peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO₂)
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Cardiovascular and Physiological Measurements, Respiratory Function
data.Overall effect: Both breathing techniques decreased respiratory frequency and blood pressure, and increased HRV and oxygen saturation; Mahat breathing had slightly greater effects

data.Author: Dillard
data.Title: Slow Breathing Reduces Biomarkers of Stress in Response to a Virtual Reality Active Shooter Training Drill
data.Duration of intervention/study: single-session intervention with short-term follow-up at 30 minutes post-drill
data.Duration of breathing exercise: 5 minutes before and 5 minutes after the VR-ASD
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Physiological biomarkers of stress (salivary alpha-amylase [sAA], SIgA)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Heart rate (HR), State Anxiety Inventory (SAI) scores
data.Overall effect:
In conclusion, the VR-ASD resulted in significant increases in the physiological stress markers sAA and SIgA. Both slow breathing interventions (SB1 and SB2) were effective at preventing increases in the salivary stress marker (sAA) in individuals post-VR-ASD 
exposure.

data.Author: Garcia
data.Title:
Assessment of well-being using Fitbit technology in college students, faculty
and staff completing breathing meditation during COVID-19: A pilot study
data.Condition: College students, faculty, and staff from a public university
data.Primary Outcome of interest: breathing & fit bits used to measure stress levels in college students
data.Primary Outcome Category: Respiratory Function, Anxiety/depression, General well-being/quality of life
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: assessment tools used to measure perceived stress, anxiety, mindfulness, and physical activity among participants
data.Secondary Outcome Category: Anxiety/depression, General well-being/quality of life, Physical Fitness
data.Overall effect:
This pilot study suggests that daily 
breathing meditation combined with wearing a Fitbit device is a feasible intervention among college populations and may help reduce anxiety, increase physical activity, and increase time spent in rapid eye movement (REM) sleep.

data.Author: Lee
data.Title:
The Effect of Deep and Slow Breathing on Retention and 
Cognitive Function in the Elderly Population
data.Duration of intervention/study: pre-test (PT), 30 minutes after learning (STT), and 24 hours after learning (LTT).
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Changes in the cognitive functions of learning and memory was assesed through some tests
data.Overall effect: This study revealed that applying DSB can enhance the ability of elderly individuals to process new cognitive tasks and improve cognitive function

data.Author: Natarajan
data.Title: Mindful breathing as an effective technique in the management of hypertension
data.Primary Outcome of interest: Change in systolic and diastolic blood pressure (immediate and over time)
data.Secondary Outcome of interest: Dose-response effect; influence of baseline hypertension status and medication use
data.Overall effect: Positive: Immediate and short-term blood pressure reduction

data.Author: Singh, M
data.Title: Functional connectivity and power spectral density analysis of EEG signals in trained practitioners of Bhramari pranayama
data.Primary Outcome of interest: EEG-based functional connectivity and power spectral density changes
data.Overall effect: Increased alpha and theta power during Bhramari; enhanced functional connectivity across brain regions
